The Executive Director is an American stationed at the World Peace Through Law offices in Washington.
b asked the Minister for Trade and Industry, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that uniform freight rates apply between Europe and all main Australian ports?
With the standardisation of rail gauges linking Fremantle and Brisbane, would it be an advantage if the uniform rate were abolished?
Would its abolition mean a quicker turn round of ships at Fremantle and a consequent reduction in port charges?
If so, will he take action to have the uniform freight rate arrangement altered so that Western Australia can take advantage of its geographic position?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.label: l.
item.para: Yes. 2 and 3. There would be an overall economic advantage only if the saving in costs resulting from ships turning round in Fremantle was greater than the extra cost of railing eastern States cargo to and from Fremantle. There is no evidence that this is so for the vast majority of cargoes at present moving.

In view of the foregoing and the fact that in this trade a call at Fremantle is normally an integral part of the service to all other Australian states, there appears to be no basis to seek to have the uniform freight rate altered.

talk.start.para: s asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice -

item.para: What is the present strength of the Citizen Military Forces?
Has the Government any intention of using the C.M.F. in order to augment the Australian Military Forces in Vietnam?
What is the cost of maintaining the C.M.F.?
What proportion of the Army vote is spent on the C.M.F.?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: As at 27th July 1966-32,187.
The role of the C.M.F. is twofold-

item.label: (a)
item.para: To provide back up forces in a situation of defence emergency in the time that would be required for the support of the Regular Army and National Servicemen.

item.label: (b)
item.para: To provide for the expansion in the Army in the case of general war. The present situation in Vietnam does not require the employment of the C.M.F. in fulfilment of its stated role. However, some C.M.F. personnel are currently serving in Vietnam. These are members who specifically volunteered for such service and successfully completed the necessary full-time training.
The annual cost of maintaining the C.M.F. including maintenance of the A.R.A. Cadre Staff involved, is estimated at $27.4 million.
The cost of the C.M.F., as stated above, represents 8.4 per cent, of the total Army vote.

talk.start.para: n asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice -

item.para: How many weapons were captured in the engagement which took place between Australian Forces and the Vietcong on 18th August 1966 in the Baria area, South Vietnam?
In which countries were these weapons manufactured?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: Fifty-three weapons.
Fifty-one in Communist China, one in United Soviet Socialist Republic, one of unknown origin.

talk.start.para: m asked the Minister representing the Acting Minister for External Affairs, upon notice -

item.para: Is it necessary to amend the terms of reference of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East to include the Territory of Papua and New Guinea before the Asian Development Bank can assist the Territory?
Why did Australia agree to the terms of reference being amended in 1963 to include only continental Australia?
What steps has Australia taken to have the Territory now included in the terms of reference?

item.para: Did the economic survey mission to the Territory of Papua and New Guinea, which was organised by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development at the Government's request, recommend in September 1964 (a) that the basis of the subsidy now paid to Burns Philp and Co. Ltd. be changed to a service subsidy with control over the level and structure of rates and frequency of service and (b) that this subsidy be administered jointly by a committee appointed by his Department and by the Territory Administration?

question.para: What was the total sum expended by the
Department of Supply in (a) Queensland and (b) all States during each of the financial years 1964-65 and 1965-66?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Supply has supplied the following information -

answer.para: Expenditures incurred by the Department of Supply in the financial years 1964-65 and 1965-66 relating to appropriations and trust fund were as follows -

talk.start.para: n asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: What amount was expended upon the Snowy Mountains Scheme in each year to 30th June 1966?
What amount in each year came from (a) general revenue and (b) loans?

talk.start.para: - The Treasurer has supplied the following information -

answer.para: The amounts expended on the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Scheme in each financial year to 30th June 1966, dissected as between Consolidated Revenue Fund and Loan Fund, are -
